question_text: What is global date of Initial Application of IFRS 17 for insurance companies under National Insurance Commission's supervision? When did IFRS 17 Standard start applying?
explanation: IFRS 17 is effective for annual reporting periods beginning on or after 1 January 2023, which is the global initial application date.

question_text: When the National Insurance Commission (NIC) is supervising insurers, which of the methods below does it NOT expect to see as an IFRS 17 application method?
explanation: IFRS 17 recognises three measurement approaches: General Measurement Model (GMM), Premium Allocation Approach (PAA) and Variable Fee Approach (VFA). 'General Allocation Approach' is not an IFRS 17 method.

question_text: Which Balance Sheet entry item below is NOT expected to be shown by an insurer while implementing IFRS 17?
explanation: Under IFRS 17, many cash flows that used to appear as 'premium receivables' are incorporated into the measurement of the insurance contract asset or liability, rather than shown as a separate 'Premium Receivables from Policyholders' line.

question_text: Which Profit & Loss entry item below is NOT expected to be shown by an insurer while implementing IFRS 17?
explanation: IFRS 17 replaces 'Gross Written Premium' with 'Insurance Revenue'. Expenses such as management expenses, acquisition costs and incurred claims continue to be recognised as part of insurance service expenses.

question_text: IFRS 17 requires that the insurer establishes a new reserve called Contractual Service Margin ('CSM'). What does this reserve represent?
explanation: The CSM represents the unearned profit the insurer will recognise as it provides insurance coverage and services in future periods.

question_text: The Risk Adjustment margin for non-financial risks can be considered as
explanation: The risk adjustment is part of the measurement of insurance contract liabilities, often viewed as part of premium and claims reserves reflecting compensation for non-financial risk.

question_text: The Liability for Incurred Claims (LIC) is composed of
option_a: Liability for Remaining Coverage & Risk Adjustment Margin
option_b: Outstanding Claim Reserves and Incurred But Not Reported Reserves & Risk Adjustment for Non-Financial Risks
option_c: Contractual Service Margin & Risk Adjustment Margin for Non-Financial Risks
option_d: Premium & Risk Adjustment Margin for Non-Financial Risks
explanation: LIC includes the present value of expected cash flows for incurred claims (reported and IBNR) plus the risk adjustment for non-financial risk associated with those cash flows.

question_text: How does IFRS 17 Standard expect the insurer and the National Insurance Commission to monitor how the discounting of cashflows is being unwound as the payment date gets closer?
option_c: Through Risk Adjustment Margin for Non-Financial Risks
explanation: The unwinding of discounting and the impact of financial risks are presented in Insurance Finance Income or Expense under IFRS 17.

question_text: If all the policyholders fully pay their premium on time, the 'Insurance Revenue' of a General Insurance Company can be compared to
explanation: When premiums are fully paid on time, the pattern of insurance revenue under IFRS 17 is broadly comparable to gross earned premium for the period.

question_text: IFRS17 has a new view on how reinsurance contracts should be treated. The spirit of the new approach is
option_a: Combine all reinsurance cashflows and policyholder cashflows to get a net position.
option_b: Separate all reinsurance cashflows from policyholder cashflows and report the net cost of reinsurance separately.
option_c: Combine only premium reinsurance cashflows and policyholder cashflows and separate claims cashflows.
option_d: Combine only claims reinsurance cashflows and policyholder cashflows and separate premium cashflows.
explanation: IFRS 17 requires reinsurance contracts held to be accounted for separately from underlying contracts, highlighting the cost and effect of reinsurance rather than netting everything together.

question_text: IFRS 17 has made some changes to how claim reserves should be treated when it comes to time value of money. The spirit of the new approach is
option_a: The insurer has the choice of discounting or not regardless of when the claim is expected to be paid
option_b: All claims expected to be paid after a year should be discounted and those expected to be paid in less than one year should also be discounted.
option_c: All claims expected to be paid after a year should be discounted and those expected to be paid in less than one year can be discounted or not depending on the choice of the insurer.
option_d: All claims must be discounted regardless of expected payment date.
explanation: IFRS 17 requires discounting where the time value of money is significant (typically long-tail claims). For shorter-duration claims where the time value is not significant, discounting may not be required.

question_text: Some people say adoption of IFRS 17 should be encouraged by regulators, such as National Insurance Commission (NIC), because it encourages CASH and CARRY by
option_a: Not considering Premium Receivables in the Balance Sheet
option_c: It considers premium only if claims have been paid
explanation: IFRS 17 focuses revenue recognition on services provided and cash flows actually expected to be collected, reducing recognition of income from uncollected premiumsâ€”hence the 'cash and carry' notion.

question_text: When an insurer discounts its liabilities at a higher rate than what it is expecting to earn, the National Insurance Commission (NIC) can easily detect this in the Profit & Loss Account by looking at
explanation: A mismatch between discount rates applied to liabilities and the actual investment return will show up in the net financial result (combining finance income on assets and finance expense on insurance liabilities).

question_text: Under the General Measurement Model (GMM), the insurance contract liabilities or assets are composed of
option_a: Liability for Remaining Coverage & Risk Adjustment Margin
option_b: Liability for Remaining Coverage & Liability for Incurred Claims
option_c: Contractual Service Margin & Liability for Incurred Claims
option_d: Premium, Outstanding Claim Reserves and Incurred But Not Reported Reserves
explanation: Under IFRS 17's GMM, the net position for insurance contracts is split between Liability for Remaining Coverage (LRC) and Liability for Incurred Claims (LIC), which together may form a net liability or asset.
